title: Benjamin Valderrama
text:
Research interests
My research focuses in using computational approaches to better understand the role of the gut microbiome in human health. My three main research interests are:

Gut microbiome modulation of gut barrier integrity and its effects on host health
Expanding our understanding of the gut microbiome from underrepresented communities
Probiotic development

title: Benjamin Valderrama
text:
Scientific output
You can visit my Google Scholar profile and ORCID for a full list of publications. Additionally, you can take a look at my GitHub account to see some projects I‚Äôm currently working on too.

title: Benjamin Valderrama
text:
Benjamin Valderrama






Bluesky Github Scholar



Short Bio
I‚Äôm a Computational Biologist üíªüß¨ with working experience in Academia, Industry, and at their interface. I‚Äôve also served as a consultant in research projects involving the analysis of multidimensional biological data.
I‚Äôm currently doing my PhD, where I‚Äôm focusing in developing and applying computational methods to better understand the microbiome-gut-brain axis. I work under the supervision of Professors John F. Cryan and Gerard Clarke at the APC microbiome Ireland.
In my daily life I like reading (mostly non-fiction), hiking, drinking coffee and doing 3D design and printing.


Research interests
My research focuses in three areas:


Microbiome modulation of the gut barrier integrity and its effects on host gut-brain health.
The gut microbiome of underrepresented population and its implications on brain health.
Probiotics and Psychobiotics development.

title: Benjamin Valderrama
text:
About me
I finished my 4 years-long bachelor degree in biology at the Pontificia Universidad Catolica of Chile in 2019. During those years I volunteered at a laboratory working on the microbiome-gut-brain axis using D. melanogaster as an animal model. On 2020 I did an extra year of training that is mandatory to work in Chilean industries. It is during this period when I discover my love for computational biology, while I was involved in the characterization of new probiotics for the aquaculture industry. On 2021 I had a small detour working as a automation specialist at a Chilean company, where I developed python scripts to control a pipeting robot. On 2022 I joined the APC microbiome Ireland to work as a bioinformatician and in 2023 I started my PhD under the supervision of Professors John F. Cryan and Gerard Clarke.

title: The South American MicroBiome Archive (saMBA)
text:
The South American Microbiome Archive (saMBA) is the largest archive of gut microbiome samples from South American populations analysed under an unified workflow. The main outputs generated while building saMBA can be downloaded from this Zenodo repository, and the analysis of those outputs is described in this article. The motivation to start this project is described here.
Note that the workflow was made publicly available to propel microbiome research globally, specially in other neglected world regions. If interested in collaborating, please get in touch. Below there is a list of things I have in mind but I‚Äôm curious to see what you have to say.

Plans for future developments
Below I share some ideas I‚Äôd like to implement to improve saMBA and to make it a useful resource for the entire community in the long run. I made this public to keep the users informed and to invite people interested in contributing in any of these points to reach out.


Build an R package to facilitate the download of the outputs in Zenodo
Implement the workflow as a Docker image so users can deploy it.

Update (01/Jun/2025): Docker image here

Expand saMBA (the resource) to include samples from other bodysites of southamericans.
Expand the workflow to include the analysis of projects using whole genome sequencing.

title: The Middle Author Bioinformatician
text: ‚ÄúThe Middle Author Bioinformatician‚Äù is where I write about Bioinformatics, Gut Microbiome, The Microbiome-Gut-Brain axis and Science in general. I also share some personal thoughts and document my path to becoming more than just another middle author bioinformatician.

title: My work on the news
section: Open Science: Transform your house into a laboratory
text:
Open Science: Transform your house into a laboratory

A university news outlet covered the release of our science communication book. The book has instructions to perform simple scientific experiments and their explanations. It was released for free during the COVID-19 lockdown to encourage kids to learn about science. The book is free online (Spanish only).
